questions.question_text:
Northern Trail Outfitters is in the final stages of merging two Salesforce orgs, but needs to keep the retiring org available for a short period of time for lead management as it is connected to multiple public web site forms. The Sales department has requested that new leads are available in the new Salesforce instance within 30 minutes.

Which approach will require the least amount of development effort?

choices.B: Use the Tooling API with Process Builder to insert leads in real time.
choices.A: Use the Composite REST API to aggregate multiple leads in a single call.
choices.C: Call the Salesforce REST API to insert the lead into the target system.

questions.question_text:
Northern Trail Outfitters is planning to perform nightly batch loads into Salesforce from an external system with a custom Java application using the Bulk API. The CIO is curious about monitoring recommendations for the jobs from the technical architect.

Which recommendation will help meet the requirements?

discussion.content: Answer A. Not B because it doesn't address specific errors and it relies on a dev manually checking the error log. Not C, because, in Salesforce, we wouldn't want devs monitoring logs outside of Sf. A is the best because it addreses the problem technically and provides an automated and reportable way to monitor a regular (nightly) batching operation. This way the CIO, the Admin or Dev can simply view the report.

Selected Answer: A
I'd use the trigger, and write to a custom object, and list view

choices.A: Write the error response from the Bulk API status to a custom error logging object in Salesforce using an Apex trigger and create reports on the object.
choices.B: Set the Salesforce debug logs level to “finest” and add the user Id running the job to monitor in the “Debug Logs” in the setup menu.
choices.C: Use the getBatchInfo method in the Java application to monitor the status of the jobs from the Java application.

questions.question_text:
Northern Trail Outfitters is in the final stages of merging two Salesforce orgs, but needs to keep the retiring org available for a short period of time for lead management as it is connected to multiple public web site forms. The Sales department has requested that new leads are available in the new Salesforce instance within 30 minutes.
Which two approaches will require the least amount of development effort? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
I think composite is more complex than ”simple” REST.

comments.content: Composit is not so complex than REST its Salesforce Standard API which we can levelrage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
The key to this question is "least Development Effort". If the question stated "Highest performance" or "Least Network calls .." then the answer would be different ( May be Composite APIs).
Composite Batch APIs ( /composite/batch) - is out of the box feature to send multiple ( upto only 25 records in one single call) while Standard API can make 1 record in 1 call. However it takes some more development effort ( if not much , but more than for standard apis) to formatt the aggregated request and handle the failures ( especially what do you do when one or two records out of 25 requested fail ? You need to have a strategy to filter them and record or retry etc..which is a bit more effort)

Selected Answer: AB
Inserts should be happening every 30 mins as per the question. So after every 30 minutes, a composite request should be created and hit to target system, to insert all new leads created in that 30 minutes.
Simple Rest API can insert only one record at a time which does not have to wait for 30 mins. SO A& B are the answer
Composite is not needed in this case. Standard API should suffice.

According to this blog (https://sfdclesson.com/2023/07/13/seamless-integration-harnessing-the-power-of-salesforce-composite-api/#:~:text=Bulk%20data%20loading%3A%20You%20can,API%20calls%20and%20improving%20performance.) which states "You can use the composite resource to insert, update, or delete multiple records in one call, reducing the number of API calls and improving performance" the answers should be A and B

Selected Answer: AD
Correct Answer is A&D. Composite Rest API is not necessarily intended to aggregate multiple records of the same object into a single call but perform chain API calls relating different Object Records in one request. E.g. Insert Account + Opportunity associated to the returned new Account Record Id.

I think A & D
The requirement in the scenario is to ensure that new leads are available in the new Salesforce instance within 30 minutes. Using the Composite REST API to aggregate multiple leads in a single call would require waiting until a certain number of leads are collected before sending them to the target system. This delay may not be acceptable for the sales department, which requires real-time access to new leads.

Additionally, setting up the Composite REST API to aggregate leads would require custom development, which goes against the requirement of choosing approaches that require the least amount of development effort.
